results.title: The Man Who Named the World/Declaration of a Heretic
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visionaries”.
“The Man who named the World” - Professor James Lovelock is responsible for one of the most revolutionary environmental ideas - the Gaia hypothesis. This says that the planet is more than a cosmic sphere brimming with life, it is a single organism that has been alive for three and a half billion years. “Declaration of a Heretic” - Jeremy Rivkin is a professional activist. For many years his Foundation on Economic Trends has challenged the bio sciences in the court rooms. He was responsible for preventing the release of genetically engineered bacteria onto Californian strawberry crops, he’s putting the brakes on the Human Genome Project, and he’s forced the genetic engineers to conduct their experiments in an atmosphere of public scrutiny. Rated: G

group_siblings.title: In grave danger of falling food
group_siblings.creator_credit: Tony Gailey, Julian Russell and 220 Productions

group_siblings.title: In Grave danger of falling food/barefoot economist

results.title: In Grave danger of falling food/barefoot economist
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visionaries”.
In Grave Danger of Falling Food - Bill Mollison believes that the most destructive force on the planet is modern agriculture. It destroys our soils, poisons our water and produces toxic food. Instead, he has designed Permaculture, a system that uses the engineering principles of nature itself. He combines hundreds of plants and animals into a fertile self-regulating ecosystem. “Barefoot Economist” - Manfred Max-Neef is a Chilean economist trying to address the problems of Latin America. He thinks the worst solutions are those imposed from the top by financial planners, and the best are those worked out on the ground by local communities.

results.title: Greenhouse Effect
results.creator_credit: Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rob Gell’s environment series”.
The “Greenhouse Effect” is explained and the consequent predictions about climate change are detailed with reference to possible impact. Hosted by weatherman, Rob Gell.

results.title: The Weather
results.creator_credit: Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rob Gell’s environment series”.
Explains, in simple terms, the origin of weather patterns we experience each day. The origin and extent of various types of storms are investigated.

results.title: The Job
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, ABC-TV (Australia) and Michael Jenkins
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Scales of Justice Series”.
The Job is a story of naivety. Probationary Constable Leonard Webber has the makings of a good policeman, but his ideals bring him into conflict with his colleagues. His lack of experience makes him vulnerable and his training has not prepared him for the system, how it works and the rationalisation of the double dealings. Rated: M

results.title: The Numbers
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, ABC-TV (Australia) and Michael Carson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Scales of Justice Series”.
The Numbers is a story of ambitious and cunning manipulation. Glen Ferris is an astute young politician. At 41 he is already Attorney General, but his revolutionary reforms have weakened his standing in the Senior Cabinet. He needs the numbers, so he decides to use his controversial bill to take on vice-king Artie Roach, a move which makes him a crusader in the public eye while causing discussion in his own parliamentary wing. Rated: M

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, ABC-TV (Australia) and Michael Carson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Scales of Justice Series”.
The Game is a story of jealousy and conflict, personal and professional. Detective Sergeant Draffin and Miles are both from the same mould. Both are ruthlessly ambitious, both boast a reputation of being first class operators, and both are very confident of their ability. However, neither is used to sharing the limelight, and when Draffin is transferred to the Drug Squad, Miles’ home territory, the scene is set for a major confrontation. Rated: M
